lesson.subject: language
lesson.title: The Cyrillic Code I
lesson.subtitle: True Friends, False Friends, and Strangers
lesson.description: Learner can recognize and pronounce 19 Cyrillic letters
objectives: Learner can recognize and pronounce 19 Cyrillic letters
Learner can identify "True Friends" (letters that look/sound like English)
Learner can identify "False Friends" (look familiar, sound different)
Learner can read 35 international cognates in Ukrainian

sections.name: –í—Å—Ç—É–ø
sections.content:
## warm-up
**Welcome to Ukraine.**

Imagine the plane wheels touching down on the runway. You are at **–ë–æ—Ä–∏—Å–ø—ñ–ª—å** [üîä](audio_boryspil) (Boryspil) International Airport, the main gateway to Kyiv. You grab your bag, step into the terminal, and look up. The signs are blue and yellow. Some letters look comforting and familiar: A, T, O, M. Others look vaguely recognizable but wrong, like a backwards "N" or a "P" where an "R" should be. And some look like alien artifacts or tridents.

Panic? No. This is where your journey begins. You might think you need to memorize 33 random symbols from scratch, but that is a myth. You already know more than half of the Ukrainian alphabet. You just don't know *that you know it*.

In this module, we are not going to chant "A, B, C." We are going to play the role of a codebreaker. We will treat the alphabet as a cipher that has three distinct layers: friends you can trust, tricksters that lie to you, and strangers you haven't met yet. By the end of this hour, you won't just know letters; you will be reading words like **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** [üîä](audio_taksi) (Taxi) and **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro) (Metro) without a second thought.

> üí° **Did You Know?**
> The Cyrillic alphabet was **NOT** invented by Russians! It was created in the late 9th century in the First Bulgarian Empire. It is named after Saint Cyril, a missionary from Byzantium, but it was likely developed by his students, particularly Saint Clement of Ohrid. They based it largely on the Greek alphabet, which explains why so many "math symbols" (like $\pi$ and $\rho$) appear as letters here. Ukraine adopted it over a thousand years ago, long before modern Russia existed.

## presentation

### The First Layer: True Friends
Let's start with the easiest layer. These letters are "True Friends" because they are honest. They look exactly like their English counterparts (the Latin alphabet) and they make the exact same sounds. If you see **–ê**, you say "Ah". If you see **–ö**, you say "K".

There are seven of these honest letters: **–ê, –ï, –Ü, –û, –ö, –ú, –¢**.

Think of the word **–ê–¢–û–ú** [üîä](audio_atom). In Ukrainian, it is **–ê–¢–û–ú**. Same letters, same meaning.
Think of **–ú–ê–ú–ê** [üîä](audio_mama). It's **–ú–ê–ú–ê**.
Think of **–ö–û–¢** [üîä](audio_kot). It sounds like "cot", but it means "cat" (specifically a male cat).

| Letter | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–ê –∞** | /a/ as in f**a**ther | **–ê** | /a/ (Ah!) | [üîä](audio_a) |
| **–ï –µ** | /…õ/ as in p**e**t | **–ï** | /e/ (Eh?) | [üîä](audio_e) |
| **–Ü —ñ** | /i/ as in mach**i**ne | **–Ü** | /i/ (Ee) | [üîä](audio_i) |
| **–û –æ** | /…î/ as in m**o**re | **–û** | /o/ (Oh) | [üîä](audio_o) |
| **–ö –∫** | /k/ as in **k**ite | **–ö** | /k/ | [üîä](audio_k) |
| **–ú –º** | /m/ as in **m**ap | **–ú** | /m/ | [üîä](audio_m) |
| **–¢ —Ç** | /t/ as in **t**ent | **–¢** | /t/ | [üîä](audio_t) |

> ‚ö° **Pro Tip:**
> Ukrainian **–¢** is a "dental" sound. Your tongue should touch your teeth, not the roof of your mouth like in English. It sounds sharper, crisper, and less "airy" than the English T. Try saying "Tennis" but touch your teeth. That's the Ukrainian **–¢**.

### The Second Layer: False Friends
Now we enter the danger zone. These letters are the "tricksters". They look incredibly familiar‚Äîyou see a "B", a "P", an "H", a "C", an "X", and a "y". But if you pronounce them like English letters, you will be speaking gibberish. These are "False Friends".

Why do they look like this? Because they come from Greek.
- The letter **–†** looks like a "P", but it is the Greek *Rho*. It makes the **R** sound (rolled, like in Spanish or Italian).
- The letter **–•** looks like an "X", but it is the Greek *Chi*. It makes the heavy **H** sound (like in "Loch Ness").

| Letter | Looks like | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|------------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–í –≤** | B | /v/ as in **v**et | **–í**—ñ–∑–∞ | /vi-za/ | [üîä](audio_v) |
| **–ù –Ω** | H | /n/ as in **n**et | **–ù**—ñ | /ni/ | [üîä](audio_n) |
| **–† —Ä** | P | /r/ trilled (rolled) | **–†**–∞–¥—ñ–æ | /ra-di-o/ | [üîä](audio_r) |
| **–° —Å** | C | /s/ as in **s**un (never /k/!) | **–°**—É–ø | /sup/ | [üîä](audio_s) |
| **–£ —É** | y | /u/ as in m**oo**n | **–£**—Ä–æ–∫ | /u-rok/ | [üîä](audio_u) |
| **–• —Ö** | X | /x/ as in lo**ch** (hard H) | **–•**–∞–æ—Å | /kha-os/ | [üîä](audio_kh) |

Let's decode a few "False Friend" words.
You see **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran). Your brain says "Pectopah". But now you know:
- P = R
- C = S
- H = N
It reads **RESTORAN**.

You see **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro). It's not "Metpo". It is **METRO**.
You see **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup). It's not "Cyn". It is **SUP**.

> üîç **Myth Buster**
> **Myth:** "Ukrainian is just a dialect of Russian."
> **Fact:** Ukrainian is a separate East Slavic language with a distinct history. While they share an alphabet (mostly), the sounds are different. For example, the Ukrainian **–ì** (H) is soft and breathy, while the Russian G is hard (like in "Go"). The Ukrainian **–û** is always pronounced "O", whereas in Russian it often turns into "A" when unstressed. They are as different as Spanish and Portuguese.

### The Third Layer: New Friends
Finally, we meet the strangers. These letters don't look like English letters at all. They are unique shapes that you simply need to memorize. But the good news is: they usually make very simple sounds.

- **–ë** looks like a 6 or a b with a hat. It is **B**.
- **–ì** looks like a gallows or a hook. It is the breathy **H** (like in "**h**ome").
- **–î** looks like a fortress or a table. It is **D**.
- **–ó** looks like the number 3. It creates the **Z** sound.
- **–õ** looks like an upside-down V or a lambda. It is **L**.
- **–ü** looks like a mathematical Pi ($\pi$) or a doorway. It is **P**.
- **–§** looks like a circle with a line through it. It is **F**.

| Letter | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–ë –±** | /b/ as in **b**oy | **–ë**–∞–Ω–∫ | /bank/ | [üîä](audio_b) |
| **–î –¥** | /d/ as in **d**og | **–î**—ñ–º | /dim/ | [üîä](audio_d) |
| **–ó –∑** | /z/ as in **z**oo | **–ó**–æ–Ω–∞ | /zo-na/ | [üîä](audio_z) |
| **–õ –ª** | /l/ as in **l**ove | **–õ**–∞–º–ø–∞ | /lam-pa/ | [üîä](audio_l) |
| **–ü –ø** | /p/ as in **p**ot | **–ü**–∞—Ä–∫ | /park/ | [üîä](audio_p) |
| **–§ —Ñ** | /f/ as in **f**un | **–§**–æ—Ç–æ | /fo-to/ | [üîä](audio_f) |

**Reading Practice:**
- **–ë–ê–ù–ö** [üîä](audio_bank) (bank) ‚Äî Bank
- **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park) (park) ‚Äî Park
- **–§–û–¢–û** [üîä](audio_foto) (fo-to) ‚Äî Photo
- **–õ–ê–ú–ü–ê** [üîä](audio_lampa) (lam-pa) ‚Äî Lamp
- **–ó–û–ù–ê** [üîä](audio_zona) (zo-na) ‚Äî Zone

> üé¨ **Pop Culture Moment: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.**
> The famous Ukrainian video game series **S.T.A.L.K.E.R.** is set in the Chornobyl Exclusion **Zone**. In Ukrainian, "Zone" is **–ó–û–ù–ê** (Zona). When you see **–ó**, think of the **Z**ig-zag shape. The developers, GSC Game World, are based in Kyiv!

### Cultural Insight: The Streetscape
When you walk through a Ukrainian city like Lviv or Odesa, the streetscape is a mix of old and new. You will see **–ê–ü–¢–ï–ö–ê** [üîä](audio_apteka) (Pharmacy - Apteka) on almost every corner. You will see **–ë–ê–†** [üîä](audio_bar) (Bar) and **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_kafe) (Kafe). You might see a sign for **–ù–û–¢–ê–†–Ü–£–°** [üîä](audio_notarius) (Notary) or **–ê–î–í–û–ö–ê–¢** [üîä](audio_advokat) (Lawyer).

Reading these signs is the first step to feeling "at home". You stop being a foreigner who sees random shapes, and you become a reader who sees meaning. Even with just these 19 letters, you can read about 30% of the signs on the street.

## practice

Now, let's combine these three groups to read real international words used in Ukraine every day. Imagine you are walking down **–•—Ä–µ—â–∞—Ç–∏–∫** (Khreshchatyk) Street in Kyiv. You see these signs.

**1. Places:**
- **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro) (Metro) ‚Äî Subway
- **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_kafe) (Kafe) ‚Äî Caf√©
- **–ë–ê–†** [üîä](audio_bar) (Bar) ‚Äî Bar
- **–¢–ï–ê–¢–†** [üîä](audio_teatr) (Teatr) ‚Äî Theater
- **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park) (Park) ‚Äî Park
- **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran) (Restoran) ‚Äî Restaurant

**2. Food:**
- **–°–ê–õ–ê–¢** [üîä](audio_salat) (Salat) ‚Äî Salad
- **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup) (Sup) ‚Äî Soup
- **–ü–Ü–¶–ê** [üîä](audio_pitsa) (Pitsa) ‚Äî Pizza (Note: –¶ is T+S, we will learn it later, but here it helps!)
- **–ë–ê–ù–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_banan) (Banan) ‚Äî Banana
- **–õ–ò–ú–û–ù** [üîä](audio_lymon) (Lymon) ‚Äî Lemon
- **–ö–ê–ö–ê–û** [üîä](audio_kakao) (Kakao) ‚Äî Cocoa
- **–ö–ê–í–ê** [üîä](audio_kava) (Kava) ‚Äî Coffee

**3. People:**
- **–°–¢–£–î–ï–ù–¢** [üîä](audio_student) (Student) ‚Äî Student
- **–¢–£–†–ò–°–¢** [üîä](audio_turyst) (Turyst) ‚Äî Tourist
- **–î–û–ö–¢–û–†** [üîä](audio_doktor) (Doktor) ‚Äî Doctor
- **–ê–ö–¢–û–†** [üîä](audio_aktor) (Aktor) ‚Äî Actor

Let's look at a dialogue. Two students, **–û–∫—Å–∞–Ω–∞** (Oksana) and **–†–æ–º–∞–Ω** (Roman), are meeting near the metro.

**Oksana:** –ü—Ä–∏–≤—ñ—Ç! (Pryvit - Hi!)
**Roman:** –ü—Ä–∏–≤—ñ—Ç, –û–∫—Å–∞–Ω–æ!
**Oksana:** –¶–µ –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ "–¢–µ–∞—Ç—Ä–∞–ª—å–Ω–∞"? (Is this Metro "Teatralna"?)
**Roman:** –¢–∞–∫, —Ü–µ –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ. (Yes, this is the metro.)
**Oksana:** –ê –¥–µ –∫–∞—Ñ–µ? (And where is the caf√©?)
**Roman:** –ö–∞—Ñ–µ —Ç–∞–º. (The caf√© is there.)

Notice the structure: **–¶–µ X** (This is X). **–î–µ X?** (Where is X?). Simple, right?

## production

Now you are ready to navigate a Ukrainian city map. You have the tools to decode signs.

Imagine you are hungry. You see a sign: **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù "–û–î–ï–°–ê"**.
- **–†** is R.
- **–ï** is E.
- **–°** is S.
- **–¢** is T.
- **–û** is O.
- **–†** is R.
- **–ê** is A.
- **–ù** is N.
= **RESTORAN**.

Next door, you see **–ë–ê–ù–ö**.
- **–ë** is B.
- **–ê** is A.
- **–ù** is N.
- **–ö** is K.
= **BANK**.

You check your **–¢–ï–õ–ï–§–û–ù** (Phone). You want to call a **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** (Taxi).
You are reading Ukrainian!

---


---

sections.name: –ü—ñ–¥—Å—É–º–æ–∫
sections.content:
In this module, you unlocked the first part of the Cyrillic code. You learned:
1.  **True Friends** (–ê, –ö, –ú...) are easy.
2.  **False Friends** (–í, –ù, –†...) are tricksters‚Äîwatch out for them!
3.  **New Letters** (–ë, –§, –õ...) are just new shapes for familiar sounds.

You can already read words like **–ú–ï–¢–†–û**, **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü**, and **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù**. In the next module, we will learn the "unique" letters that give Ukrainian its distinct sound. –î–æ –ø–æ–±–∞—á–µ–Ω–Ω—è! (Goodbye!)

  - Learner can read 35 international cognates in Ukrainian
  - Learner can distinguish Ukrainian "–ò" from "–Ü"
---

# Lesson Content

## warm-up
**Welcome to Ukraine.**

Imagine the plane wheels touching down on the runway. You are at **–ë–æ—Ä–∏—Å–ø—ñ–ª—å** [üîä](audio_boryspil) (Boryspil) International Airport, the main gateway to Kyiv. You grab your bag, step into the terminal, and look up. The signs are blue and yellow. Some letters look comforting and familiar: A, T, O, M. Others look vaguely recognizable but wrong, like a backwards "N" or a "P" where an "R" should be. And some look like alien artifacts or tridents.

Panic? No. This is where your journey begins. You might think you need to memorize 33 random symbols from scratch, but that is a myth. You already know more than half of the Ukrainian alphabet. You just don't know *that you know it*.

In this module, we are not going to chant "A, B, C." We are going to play the role of a codebreaker. We will treat the alphabet as a cipher that has three distinct layers: friends you can trust, tricksters that lie to you, and strangers you haven't met yet. By the end of this hour, you won't just know letters; you will be reading words like **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** [üîä](audio_taksi) (Taxi) and **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro) (Metro) without a second thought.

> üí° **Did You Know?**
> The Cyrillic alphabet was **NOT** invented by Russians! It was created in the late 9th century in the First Bulgarian Empire. It is named after Saint Cyril, a missionary from Byzantium, but it was likely developed by his students, particularly Saint Clement of Ohrid. They based it largely on the Greek alphabet, which explains why so many "math symbols" (like $\pi$ and $\rho$) appear as letters here. Ukraine adopted it over a thousand years ago, long before modern Russia existed.

## presentation

### The First Layer: True Friends
Let's start with the easiest layer. These letters are "True Friends" because they are honest. They look exactly like their English counterparts (the Latin alphabet) and they make the exact same sounds. If you see **–ê**, you say "Ah". If you see **–ö**, you say "K".

There are seven of these honest letters: **–ê, –ï, –Ü, –û, –ö, –ú, –¢**.

Think of the word **–ê–¢–û–ú** [üîä](audio_atom). In Ukrainian, it is **–ê–¢–û–ú**. Same letters, same meaning.
Think of **–ú–ê–ú–ê** [üîä](audio_mama). It's **–ú–ê–ú–ê**.
Think of **–ö–û–¢** [üîä](audio_kot). It sounds like "cot", but it means "cat" (specifically a male cat).

| Letter | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–ê –∞** | /a/ as in f**a**ther | **–ê** | /a/ (Ah!) | [üîä](audio_a) |
| **–ï –µ** | /…õ/ as in p**e**t | **–ï** | /e/ (Eh?) | [üîä](audio_e) |
| **–Ü —ñ** | /i/ as in mach**i**ne | **–Ü** | /i/ (Ee) | [üîä](audio_i) |
| **–û –æ** | /…î/ as in m**o**re | **–û** | /o/ (Oh) | [üîä](audio_o) |
| **–ö –∫** | /k/ as in **k**ite | **–ö** | /k/ | [üîä](audio_k) |
| **–ú –º** | /m/ as in **m**ap | **–ú** | /m/ | [üîä](audio_m) |
| **–¢ —Ç** | /t/ as in **t**ent | **–¢** | /t/ | [üîä](audio_t) |

> ‚ö° **Pro Tip:**
> Ukrainian **–¢** is a "dental" sound. Your tongue should touch your teeth, not the roof of your mouth like in English. It sounds sharper, crisper, and less "airy" than the English T. Try saying "Tennis" but touch your teeth. That's the Ukrainian **–¢**.

### The Second Layer: False Friends
Now we enter the danger zone. These letters are the "tricksters". They look incredibly familiar‚Äîyou see a "B", a "P", an "H", a "C", an "X", and a "y". But if you pronounce them like English letters, you will be speaking gibberish. These are "False Friends".

Why do they look like this? Because they come from Greek.
- The letter **–†** looks like a "P", but it is the Greek *Rho*. It makes the **R** sound (rolled, like in Spanish or Italian).
- The letter **–•** looks like an "X", but it is the Greek *Chi*. It makes the heavy **H** sound (like in "Loch Ness").

| Letter | Looks like | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|------------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–í –≤** | B | /v/ as in **v**et | **–í**—ñ–∑–∞ | /vi-za/ | [üîä](audio_v) |
| **–ù –Ω** | H | /n/ as in **n**et | **–ù**—ñ | /ni/ | [üîä](audio_n) |
| **–† —Ä** | P | /r/ trilled (rolled) | **–†**–∞–¥—ñ–æ | /ra-di-o/ | [üîä](audio_r) |
| **–° —Å** | C | /s/ as in **s**un (never /k/!) | **–°**—É–ø | /sup/ | [üîä](audio_s) |
| **–£ —É** | y | /u/ as in m**oo**n | **–£**—Ä–æ–∫ | /u-rok/ | [üîä](audio_u) |
| **–• —Ö** | X | /x/ as in lo**ch** (hard H) | **–•**–∞–æ—Å | /kha-os/ | [üîä](audio_kh) |

Let's decode a few "False Friend" words.
You see **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran). Your brain says "Pectopah". But now you know:
- P = R
- C = S
- H = N
It reads **RESTORAN**.

You see **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro). It's not "Metpo". It is **METRO**.
You see **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup). It's not "Cyn". It is **SUP**.

> üîç **Myth Buster**
> **Myth:** "Ukrainian is just a dialect of Russian."
> **Fact:** Ukrainian is a separate East Slavic language with a distinct history. While they share an alphabet (mostly), the sounds are different. For example, the Ukrainian **–ì** (H) is soft and breathy, while the Russian G is hard (like in "Go"). The Ukrainian **–û** is always pronounced "O", whereas in Russian it often turns into "A" when unstressed. They are as different as Spanish and Portuguese.

### The Third Layer: New Friends
Finally, we meet the strangers. These letters don't look like English letters at all. They are unique shapes that you simply need to memorize. But the good news is: they usually make very simple sounds.

- **–ë** looks like a 6 or a b with a hat. It is **B**.
- **–ì** looks like a gallows or a hook. It is the breathy **H** (like in "**h**ome").
- **–î** looks like a fortress or a table. It is **D**.
- **–ó** looks like the number 3. It creates the **Z** sound.
- **–õ** looks like an upside-down V or a lambda. It is **L**.
- **–ü** looks like a mathematical Pi ($\pi$) or a doorway. It is **P**.
- **–§** looks like a circle with a line through it. It is **F**.

| Letter | Sound | Example | Reading | Audio |
|--------|-------|---------|---------|-------|
| **–ë –±** | /b/ as in **b**oy | **–ë**–∞–Ω–∫ | /bank/ | [üîä](audio_b) |
| **–î –¥** | /d/ as in **d**og | **–î**—ñ–º | /dim/ | [üîä](audio_d) |
| **–ó –∑** | /z/ as in **z**oo | **–ó**–æ–Ω–∞ | /zo-na/ | [üîä](audio_z) |
| **–õ –ª** | /l/ as in **l**ove | **–õ**–∞–º–ø–∞ | /lam-pa/ | [üîä](audio_l) |
| **–ü –ø** | /p/ as in **p**ot | **–ü**–∞—Ä–∫ | /park/ | [üîä](audio_p) |
| **–§ —Ñ** | /f/ as in **f**un | **–§**–æ—Ç–æ | /fo-to/ | [üîä](audio_f) |

**Reading Practice:**
- **–ë–ê–ù–ö** [üîä](audio_bank) (bank) ‚Äî Bank
- **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park) (park) ‚Äî Park
- **–§–û–¢–û** [üîä](audio_foto) (fo-to) ‚Äî Photo
- **–õ–ê–ú–ü–ê** [üîä](audio_lampa) (lam-pa) ‚Äî Lamp
- **–ó–û–ù–ê** [üîä](audio_zona) (zo-na) ‚Äî Zone

> üé¨ **Pop Culture Moment: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.**
> The famous Ukrainian video game series **S.T.A.L.K.E.R.** is set in the Chornobyl Exclusion **Zone**. In Ukrainian, "Zone" is **–ó–û–ù–ê** (Zona). When you see **–ó**, think of the **Z**ig-zag shape. The developers, GSC Game World, are based in Kyiv!

You will see **–ë–ê–†** [üîä](audio_bar) (Bar) and **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_kafe) (Kafe). You might see a sign for **–ù–û–¢–ê–†–Ü–£–°** [üîä](audio_notarius) (Notary) or **–ê–î–í–û–ö–ê–¢** [üîä](audio_advokat) (Lawyer).

Reading these signs is the first step to feeling "at home". You stop being a foreigner who sees random shapes, and you become a reader who sees meaning. Even with just these 19 letters, you can read about 30% of the signs on the street.

## practice

Now, let's combine these three groups to read real international words used in Ukraine every day. Imagine you are walking down **–•—Ä–µ—â–∞—Ç–∏–∫** (Khreshchatyk) Street in Kyiv. You see these signs.

**1. Places:**
- **–ú–ï–¢–†–û** [üîä](audio_metro) (Metro) ‚Äî Subway
- **–ö–ê–§–ï** [üîä](audio_kafe) (Kafe) ‚Äî Caf√©
- **–ë–ê–†** [üîä](audio_bar) (Bar) ‚Äî Bar
- **–¢–ï–ê–¢–†** [üîä](audio_teatr) (Teatr) ‚Äî Theater
- **–ü–ê–†–ö** [üîä](audio_park) (Park) ‚Äî Park
- **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_restoran) (Restoran) ‚Äî Restaurant

**2. Food:**
- **–°–ê–õ–ê–¢** [üîä](audio_salat) (Salat) ‚Äî Salad
- **–°–£–ü** [üîä](audio_sup) (Sup) ‚Äî Soup
- **–ü–Ü–¶–ê** [üîä](audio_pitsa) (Pitsa) ‚Äî Pizza (Note: –¶ is T+S, we will learn it later, but here it helps!)
- **–ë–ê–ù–ê–ù** [üîä](audio_banan) (Banan) ‚Äî Banana
- **–õ–ò–ú–û–ù** [üîä](audio_lymon) (Lymon) ‚Äî Lemon
- **–ö–ê–ö–ê–û** [üîä](audio_kakao) (Kakao) ‚Äî Cocoa
- **–ö–ê–í–ê** [üîä](audio_kava) (Kava) ‚Äî Coffee

**3. People:**
- **–°–¢–£–î–ï–ù–¢** [üîä](audio_student) (Student) ‚Äî Student
- **–¢–£–†–ò–°–¢** [üîä](audio_turyst) (Turyst) ‚Äî Tourist
- **–î–û–ö–¢–û–†** [üîä](audio_doktor) (Doktor) ‚Äî Doctor
- **–ê–ö–¢–û–†** [üîä](audio_aktor) (Aktor) ‚Äî Actor

Let's look at a dialogue. Two students, **–û–∫—Å–∞–Ω–∞** (Oksana) and **–†–æ–º–∞–Ω** (Roman), are meeting near the metro.

**Oksana:** –ü—Ä–∏–≤—ñ—Ç! (Pryvit - Hi!)
**Roman:** –ü—Ä–∏–≤—ñ—Ç, –û–∫—Å–∞–Ω–æ!
**Oksana:** –¶–µ –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ "–¢–µ–∞—Ç—Ä–∞–ª—å–Ω–∞"? (Is this Metro "Teatralna"?)
**Roman:** –¢–∞–∫, —Ü–µ –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ. (Yes, this is the metro.)
**Oksana:** –ê –¥–µ –∫–∞—Ñ–µ? (And where is the caf√©?)
**Roman:** –ö–∞—Ñ–µ —Ç–∞–º. (The caf√© is there.)

Notice the structure: **–¶–µ X** (This is X). **–î–µ X?** (Where is X?). Simple, right?

## production

Now you are ready to navigate a Ukrainian city map. You have the tools to decode signs.

Imagine you are hungry. You see a sign: **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù "–û–î–ï–°–ê"**.
- **–†** is R.
- **–ï** is E.
- **–°** is S.
- **–¢** is T.
- **–û** is O.
- **–†** is R.
- **–ê** is A.
- **–ù** is N.
= **RESTORAN**.

Next door, you see **–ë–ê–ù–ö**.
- **–ë** is B.
- **–ê** is A.
- **–ù** is N.
- **–ö** is K.
= **BANK**.

You check your **–¢–ï–õ–ï–§–û–ù** (Phone). You want to call a **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü** (Taxi).
You are reading Ukrainian!

## true-false: Letter Facts

> Decide if the statement about the alphabet is true or false.

- [x] The letter –† sounds like the English R (rolled).
  > Correct! It looks like P but sounds like R.

- [ ] The letter –ù sounds like the English H.
  > Incorrect. –ù sounds like N. The letter for H-sounds is –ì or –•.

- [x] The letter –° always sounds like S, never like K.
  > Correct! In Ukrainian, –° is always /s/.

- [ ] Cyrillic was invented by Russians.
  > Incorrect. It was created in Bulgaria in the 9th century.

- [x] The letter –• makes a sound like in "Loch".
  > Correct! It is the hard H sound.

- [ ] The letter –í sounds like B.
  > Incorrect. –í sounds like V (or W).

- [x] The letter –£ sounds like "oo" in "moon".
  > Correct!

- [ ] The letter –Ü sounds like "eye".
  > Incorrect. –Ü sounds like "ee" in "machine".

- [x] The letter –ï sounds like "e" in "pet".
  > Correct!

- [ ] The letter –ü sounds like N.
  > Incorrect. –ü is P. (Only in italics does *–ø* look like *n*).

- [x] The letter –ú is a True Friend.
  > Correct! It looks and sounds the same.

- [ ] The letter –ö is a False Friend.
  > Incorrect. –ö is a True Friend.

# Letter Groups

**True Friends:** –ê –ï –Ü –û –ö –ú –¢
**False Friends:** –í –ù –† –° –£ –•
**New Letters:** –ë –î –ó –õ –ü –§

---

# Summary

In this module, you unlocked the first part of the Cyrillic code. You learned:
1.  **True Friends** (–ê, –ö, –ú...) are easy.
2.  **False Friends** (–í, –ù, –†...) are tricksters‚Äîwatch out for them!
3.  **New Letters** (–ë, –§, –õ...) are just new shapes for familiar sounds.

You can already read words like **–ú–ï–¢–†–û**, **–¢–ê–ö–°–Ü**, and **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù**. In the next module, we will learn the "unique" letters that give Ukrainian its distinct sound. –î–æ –ø–æ–±–∞—á–µ–Ω–Ω—è! (Goodbye!)
